title: Which careers combine engineering with business? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sales engineers tend to combine both. People working in Industrial engineering in any service industry tend to focus on business systems (process improvement) Engineering managers will be making business decisions (capital investments, involved in which project are done) and this becomes more pronounced in smaller companies. I have found that engineers in smaller companies will wear lots of different hats, as opposed to large companies where careers are much more narrowly defined. The ultimate example is a small startup where you end up doing anything that needs to be done.

Any business requires some form of engineering. Take starting a product based business for example: You need to conduct market research on your potential target audience and perform a competitor analysis (there’s engineering methodology to conduct this) You need to actually develop and test a product (engineering itself) Once you launch your product, you need to gather feedback from your customers and integrate it into the next iteration (re-engineering) You also need to optimize your supply chain, analyze the habits and demographics of your customers to better market to them, and optimize operations (all engineering tools) You get the picture, engineering is everywhere. Now I know you asked for specific career titles so here’s a few: supply chain engineeringmanagement consultantcontinuous improvement or operations engineerbusiness intelligencedata engineer/scientist
